articles.headline: Divided House Passes Tax Deal in End to Latest Fiscal Standoff
articles.snippet: Ending a climactic showdown in the final hours of the 112th Congress, the House sent to President Obama legislation to avert big income tax increases on most Americans.
articles.abstract: Ending a climactic showdown in the final hours of the 112th Congress, the House sent to President Obama legislation to avert big income tax increases on most Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ending a climactic fiscal showdown in the final hours of the 112th Congress, the House late Tuesday passed and sent to President Obama legislation to avert big income tax increases on most Americans and prevent large cuts in spending for the Pentagon and other government programs.

articles.headline: For U.S. Attorney’s Office, Forfeiture From Crimes Pays  (Sometimes in Dinosaur Bones)
articles.snippet: The asset forfeiture unit of the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan recovered about $3 billion in crime proceeds in 2012, including a Tyrannosaurus skeleton worth more than $1 million.
articles.abstract: The asset forfeiture unit of the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan recovered about $3 billion in crime proceeds in 2012, including a Tyrannosaurus skeleton worth more than $1 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government runs a multibillion-dollar business in Lower Manhattan with an unusual and diverse revenue stream.

articles.headline: Malls Blossom in Russia, With a Middle Class
articles.snippet: While malls appear to be past their peak in the United States, in Russia they are luring shoppers with money to spend and investors like Morgan Stanley.
articles.abstract: While malls appear to be past their peak in the United States, in Russia they are luring shoppers with money to spend and investors like Morgan Stanley.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Shoppers who find that 250 stores aren’t enough can go ice skating, watch movies or even ride a carousel, all under a single roof.

articles.headline: Tech Giants Brace for More Scrutiny From Regulators
articles.snippet: Lobbying in the nation’s capital and overseas is likely to increase as governments worldwide revisit legislation on issues like consumer privacy and online security.
articles.abstract: Lobbying in the nation’s capital and overseas is likely to increase as governments worldwide revisit legislation on issues like consumer privacy and online security.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Silicon Valley lobbied hard in Washington in 2012, and despite some friction with regulators, fared fairly well. In 2013, though, government scrutiny is likely to grow. And with this scrutiny will come even greater efforts by the tech industry to press its case in the nation’s capital and overseas.

articles.headline: Drug Makers Losing a Bid to Foil Generic Painkillers
articles.snippet: The companies making the narcotic painkillers OxyContin and Opana have introduced tamper-resistant pills, hoping to slow adoption of the drugs’ generic versions.
articles.abstract: The companies making the narcotic painkillers OxyContin and Opana have introduced tamper-resistant pills, hoping to slow adoption of the drugs’ generic versions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Public officials have long urged makers of powerful painkillers to do more to make the medications harder to crush and abuse. But now that some companies have done so, they want something in return — a ban on generic versions of the drugs they make that do not have such tamper-resistant designs.
articles.byline: By Katie Thomas and Barry Meier

articles.headline: Even With Fiscal Agreement, Investors Facing Imminent Obstacles
articles.snippet: Economists forecast that the Congressional deal would reduce economic growth by as much as 1 percent in the first quarter of 2013.
articles.abstract: Economists forecast that the Congressional deal would reduce economic growth by as much as 1 percent in the first quarter of 2013.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the House of Representatives approval of a fiscal agreement late Tuesday, investors were expecting a rally in the markets to start the New Year. But the surge was not expected to last long, with investors and economists quickly shifting their focus to several hurdles the economy faces in the coming months.

articles.headline: Used to Hardship, Latvia Accepts Austerity, and Its Pain Eases
articles.snippet: In four years, the country has gone from the European Union’s worst economic disaster zone to a model of what is being hailed as the healing properties of deep budget cuts.
articles.abstract: In four years, the country has gone from the European Union’s worst economic disaster zone to a model of what is being hailed as the healing properties of deep budget cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIGA, Latvia — When a credit-fueled economic boom turned to bust in this tiny Baltic nation in 2008, Didzis Krumins, who ran a small architectural company, fired his staff one by one and then shut down the business. He watched in dismay as Latvia’s misery deepened under a harsh austerity drive that scythed wages, jobs and state financing for schools and hospitals.

articles.headline: Lines of Resistance on Fiscal Deal
articles.snippet: Just a few years ago, the tax deal pushed through Congress on Tuesday would have been a Republican fiscal fantasy. But times have changed.
articles.abstract: Just a few years ago, the tax deal pushed through Congress on Tuesday would have been a Republican fiscal fantasy. But times have changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just a few years ago, the tax deal pushed through Congress on Tuesday would have been a Republican fiscal fantasy, a sweeping bill that locks in virtually all of the Bush-era tax cuts, exempts almost all estates from taxation, and enshrines the former president’s credo that dividends and capital gains should be taxed equally and gently.

articles.headline: Energy Drinks Promise Edge, but Experts Say Proof Is Scant
articles.snippet: The popularity of the drinks reflects success in convincing consumers that they provide an edge, but most of their ingredients have no or little benefit, research shows.
articles.abstract: The popularity of the drinks reflects success in convincing consumers that they provide an edge, but most of their ingredients have no or little benefit, research shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Energy drinks are the fastest-growing part of the beverage industry, with sales in the United States reaching more than $10 billion in 2012 — more than Americans spent on iced tea or sports beverages like Gatorade.

articles.headline: From Congress to Halls of State, in New Hampshire, Women Rule
articles.snippet: New Hampshire, which again chose a woman to be governor, will also become the first state in history to have an all-female delegation in Washington.
articles.abstract: New Hampshire, which again chose a woman to be governor, will also become the first state in history to have an all-female delegation in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most states are red or blue. A few are purple. After the November election, New Hampshire turned pink.

articles.headline: Car Sharing Catches On as Zipcar Sells to Avis
articles.snippet: The Avis Budget Group said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire the car-sharing pioneer Zipcar for $500 million in cash.
articles.abstract: The Avis Budget Group said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire the car-sharing pioneer Zipcar for $500 million in cash.
